title: What are Linear Equations
content:
1. A linear equation is an equation of the first degree.
2. It can be expressed in the form ax + b = 0, where a and b are constants.
3. The graph of a linear equation is a straight line.

title: Standard Form of Linear Equations
content:
1. The standard form is Ax + By = C.
2. A, B, and C are real numbers, and A and B cannot be both zero.
3. This form helps identify the slope and y-intercept of the line.

title: Types of Linear Equations
content:
1. One variable: ax + b = 0.
2. Two variables: Ax + By = C.
3. Examples include equations representing lines in different contexts.

title: Solving Linear Equations
content:
1. To solve, isolate the variable on one side of the equation.
2. Use inverse operations to simplify the equation.
3. Example: to solve 2x + 3 = 11, subtract 3 and then divide by 2.

title: Graphing Linear Equations
content:
1. Use the slope-intercept form y = mx + b for graphing.
2. The slope (m) indicates the steepness, and b is the y-intercept.
3. Plot the y-intercept and use the slope to find another point.

title: Applications of Linear Equations
content:
1. Linear equations are used in real-world problems, like budgeting.
2. They help in understanding relationships in science and economics.
3. Examples include calculating distance, speed, and time.

title: Word Problems in Linear Equations
content:
1. Translate real-world situations into equations.
2. Identify variables and constants from the problem statement.
3. Solve the equation to find the answer, then interpret it in context.

title: Common Mistakes When Solving Linear Equations
content:
1. Forgetting to apply the same operation to both sides.
2. Mistaking the variable for a constant.
3. Not simplifying the equation correctly.
